title: Both Centre, States spend big on capex in Q1 FY26
summary: While this can primarily be due to a low base effect from the same quarter last year, which involved the Lok Sabha polls, analysts note that the Centre and most States have front-loaded capex this year.

title: Britannia Industries shares slide 3% after Q1 PAT edges up by just 2% YoY
summary: Britannia Industries reported a modest 2% YoY increase in PAT for Q1 FY26, reaching Rs 521 crore, with revenue up 9% to Rs 4,622 crore. Executive Vice-Chairman Varun Berry attributed the 10% sales growth to focused execution and efficiency improvements.
fullContent: Britannia Industries reported a modest 2% YoY increase in PAT for Q1 FY26, reaching Rs 521 crore, with revenue up 9% to Rs 4,622 crore. Executive Vice-Chairman Varun Berry attributed the 10% sales growth to focused execution and efficiency improvements. The company experienced double-digit growth in key states and bakery categories, supported by improving consumption trends.

title: Bharti Airtel shares rise 3% after Q1 PAT surges 43% YoY

fullContent: Bharti Airtel shares: Revenue from operations stood at Rs 49,463 crore, rising 28% YoY from Rs 38,506 crore, and also ahead of analyst expectations of Rs 48,880 crore.

title: Who Are The 'Fuqing' Group And Why Are They Mobilizing To Influence Australian Leaders
summary: Who Are The 'Fuqing' Group And Why Are They Mobilizing To Influence Australian Leaders div property="schema:text" class="clearfix text-formatted field field--name-b.
fullContent: Who Are The 'Fuqing' Group And Why Are They Mobilizing To Influence Australian Leaders Authored by Cindy Li via The Epoch Times (emphasis ours), Council debates rarely echo through international politics. But a failed motion in Cumberland, Sydney, has done just that‚Äîthanks to a group that claims to speak for Chinese Australians, but whose loyalties may lie farther afield. CCP supporters and members of the Fuqing Association posing for a photo in the Cumberland City Council building in Sydney, Australia on July 30, 2025. Cindy Li/The Epoch Times The ‚ÄúFuqing‚Äù Association‚Äînamed after the relatively small Chinese city of Fuqing‚Äîhas branches across multiple countries, and appears to be mostly active when it comes to showing support for the Chinese Communist Party‚Äôs (CCP) leadership overseas. On July 30, the Sydney-based group, which claims to represent 10,000 Chinese-Australians, mobilised to oppose a motion being considered by Cumberland City Council in Sydney‚Äôs multicultural west. The motion was aimed at officially recognising ‚ÄúWorld Falun Dafa Day‚Äù as part of the council‚Äôs annual cultural program. Falun Gong, also known as Falun Dafa, is a spiritual practice first taught in China in 1992 and based on the principles of truthfulness, compassion, and tolerance. With five sets of health-benefiting exercises and moral-guiding teachings, Falun Gong grew rapidly with an estimated 70 million to 100 million people taking it up by 1999. Perceiving its popularity as a threat, the CCP started a sweeping persecution to eliminate the faith group on July 20, 1999, which continues to this day and has seen the CCP carry out severe human rights abuses, forced organ harvesting, and more recently, transnational repression. The proposed motion (Item No: C07/25-155) before the Council recommended recognising May 13‚Äîthe birthday of Li Hongzhi, founder of Falun Dafa‚Äîas World Falun Dafa Day, a designation already widely observed in Western democracies such as Canada and the United States to acknowledge the practice‚Äôs contributions to the community, including free meditation classes and cultural performances. The motion did not garner enough support this time around, but The Epoch Times understands all councillors will continue to engage with the Falun Dafa community to understand more about the practice. Some members of the council also commented that they had to handle several requests to recognise specific celebrations for different ethnic groups. Who Are the Fuqing Association And What Are Their Motives? After the vote, however, members of the Fuqing Association took photos in front of the council building to celebrate. Fuqing is a county-level city in the coastal province of Fujian Province, and is home to 1.4 million people. In its submission against the motion, it called itself the ‚Äúlargest Australian-Chinese community organisation within the Cumberland City Council area, with a membership of over 10,000.‚Äù A figure The Epoch Times could not independently verify. The ‚Äúhometown‚Äù association‚Äîvoluntary organisations formed by immigrants who share a common place of origin‚Äî also claimed to be the ‚Äúmost representative voice of the local Chinese Australian community.‚Äù The group claimed that recognising the motion would ‚Äúcreate division.‚Äù The Fuqing group is an active player in CCP politics. Last year, members of the association mobilised thousands of local Chinese to welcome the CCP Premier Li Qiang during his official state visit to Australia. Supporters were supplied with red shirts and flags, and were encouraged to block banners from human rights demonstrators, including members of the Falun Gong community. CCP supporters (members of the Fuqing Association) jostling and attempting to block banners held by the Falun Gong community calling for human rights in China, during an official visit by CCP Premier Li Qiang in Canberra, Australia, on June 16, 2024. Luo Ya/The Epoch Times In the same year, the World Fuqing Hometown Association held its 35th anniversary celebration, attended by two members of the United Front Work Department, a party organ tasked with influencing overseas politicians and community groups. The Fuqing group‚Äôs latest actions follow the release of an official condemnation against ‚Äútransnational repression‚Äù from the G7 group of nations. ‚Äú[Transnational repression or TNR] is an aggressive form of foreign interference whereby states or their proxies attempt to intimidate, harass, harm or coerce individuals or communities outside their borders,‚Äù read the official statement. ‚ÄúIt has a chilling effect in our countries. TNR often impacts dissidents, journalists, human rights defenders, religious minorities, and those identified as part of diaspora communities.‚Äù What Started as Benign, Became Co-Opted: Professor Li Yuanhua, a former professor at Capital Normal University in Beijing who is now based in Sydney, said the CCP had taken advantage of Chinese people‚Äôs patriotism. ‚ÄúThey were originally genuine hometown associations, formed by people from the same region, but later, most were co-opted by the CCP,‚Äù he told The Epoch Times. ‚ÄúNow, nearly all such associations‚Äîover 90 percent‚Äîwhile registered in Australia, are also required to register with the Chinese consulate. ‚ÄúThe leaders of these hometown associations must submit their detailed personal information to the CCP and follow its directives. Many of them are listed as ‚Äòmember organisations‚Äô of the Australian Council for the Promotion of the Peaceful Reunification of China, which is widely regarded as one of the CCP‚Äôs key overseas front groups.‚Äù He added that the leaders and core members of these organisations are all Australian citizens. The Council made headlines years ago for its link to billionaire Huang Xiangmo, who was accused of influencing former Labor Senator Sam Dastyari, as well as Yang Dongdong, who heads the similarly named Australian Council for the Promotion of the Reunification of China. Yang himself has been accused by China expert Clive Hamilton of nurturing ‚Äúintimate and long-standing links to the Chinese consulate in Sydney‚Äù and has moved to ‚Äúadvance the objectives of the CCP.‚Äù A friend of Yang, Councillor Cedric Spencer of Sydney‚Äôs Ku-ring-gai Council, recently tried to attribute the Liberal Party‚Äôs loss of the seat of Bradfield‚Äîamong a host of other reasons‚Äîto former federal MP Paul Fletcher‚Äôs relationship with a member of the Falun Gong community. CCP‚Äôs Overseas United Front Tactics The Fuqing Association‚Äôs movements are not in isolation. Another hometown association, the Hubei Association, is also under investigation for encouraging volunteers to hand out how-to-vote cards for Teal independent Monique Ryan in the Melbourne electorate of Kooyong ahead of the May election. The Hubei Association has been accused of having ties to the United Front Work Department. Australian Strategic Policy Institute (ASPI) warned of the dangers of the CCP‚Äôs United Front tactics in its 2020 report, ‚ÄúThe party speaks for you.‚Äù Authored by Alex Joske, the report reveals that the United Front system extends far beyond China‚Äôs borders in a complex, often covert effort to expand its influence among ethnic minorities, religious groups, and political, business, and scientific communities. ‚ÄúDiplomats might see United Front work as ‚Äòpublic diplomacy‚Äô or ‚Äòpropaganda‚Äô but fail to appreciate the extent of related covert activities. Security officials may be alert to criminal activity or espionage while underestimating the significance of open activities that facilitate it,‚Äù Joske wrote. Members of the Fuqing Association took a photo in front of the Cumberland council building to celebrate their success on July 30, 2025. Supplied Councillor Helen Hughes, who voted for the proposed motion to recognise World Falun Dafa Day, said it also served to highlight that the persecution of Falun Dafa is still ongoing. ‚ÄúThis document [from Fuqing Association] doesn‚Äôt really give what I consider to be a real reason in any fact. This is not being conscientiously decent for people who are experiencing this‚Äîthe persecutions, etc.,‚Äù she told The Epoch Times. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just heartbreaking.‚Äù Hughes was moved when she heard a member of the Falun Dafa community tell the council about how she could not return to China after her parents died due to the persecution. ‚ÄúTo have that happen personally, that would be just so heartbreaking, and I really feel for them,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI genuinely was hurtful that they were not being supported in the level that they ought to be.‚Äù The Australian Security Intelligence Organisation (ASIO) told The Epoch Times that, consistent with long-standing practice, it does not comment on specific groups or individuals. Attempts to contact the Sydney branch of the Fuqing Association for comment were unsuccessful, as no official website or publicly listed contact details could be found. Tyler Durden Tue, 08/05/2025 - 23:25

title: US market curbs to hit India‚Äôs manufacturing ambitions, but domestic demand to stay strong: Moody's
summary: Moody's Ratings warns that new US tariffs, including a 25% duty on Indian imports starting August 7th and a potential penalty on Russian imports, will hinder India's manufacturing ambitions, especially in electronics.
fullContent: Moody's Ratings warns that new US tariffs, including a 25% duty on Indian imports starting August 7th and a potential penalty on Russian imports, will hinder India's manufacturing ambitions, especially in electronics. While these measures disadvantage India compared to other APAC exporters, Moody's expects India's strong domestic demand and thriving services sector to remain resilient.

title: June sees first decline in SUV sales in India in over five years amid economic challenges
summary: India's SUV sales experienced their first decline in over five years in June, dropping by 2.1% due to factors like IT layoffs and economic uncertainties. This slowdown, coupled with sluggish overall car demand, suggests potential buyer fatigue.

title: ED questions Anil Ambani in Rs 17,000-cr loan fraud probe
summary: Anil Ambani was questioned by the Enforcement Directorate for over nine hours regarding an alleged ‚Çπ17,000 crore bank loan fraud case. The ED has summoned other individuals linked to the Reliance Group, including Amitabh Jhunjhunwala and Sateesh Seth, for questioning.
fullContent: Anil Ambani was questioned by the Enforcement Directorate for over nine hours regarding an alleged ‚Çπ17,000 crore bank loan fraud case. The ED has summoned other individuals linked to the Reliance Group, including Amitabh Jhunjhunwala and Sateesh Seth, for questioning. The agency is also investigating the actions taken by banks concerning the non-repayment of loans by Anil Ambani's companies.

title: Trump targets tariff evasion, with eye on China
summary: Donald Trump's administration is increasing tariffs on goods routed through third countries. This targets potential tariff evasion, especially by Chinese companies. The US aims to reduce reliance on Chinese supply chains.
fullContent: Donald Trump's administration is increasing tariffs on goods routed through third countries. This targets potential tariff evasion, especially by Chinese companies. It may be difficult to enforce, particularly in countries friendly to China.

Trade negotiations continue with scheduled talks in August.

title: Watch: Trump Learns Ukrainian Military Now Enlisting Elderly, Mentally Handicapped
summary: Watch: Trump Learns Ukrainian Military Now Enlisting Elderly, Mentally Handicapped div property="schema:text" class="clearfix text-formatted field field--name-body.
fullContent: Watch: Trump Learns Ukrainian Military Now Enlisting Elderly, Mentally Handicapped As we covered last week, Ukrainian parliament has decided that ‚Äúcitizens aged 60+ can now enlist under contract during martial law.‚Äù ZeroHedge White House reporter Liam Cosgrove asked President Trump about this and other disturbing recruitment practices by our "Eastern Ally." Trump‚Äôs told for the FIRST time Ukraine‚Äôs forcing young men, disabled, even over-60s to fight TRUMP: ‚ÄòThis is BIDEN‚ÄôS war‚Ä¶ haven‚Äôt heard about 60yo men etc‚Äô Think US President‚Äôs being given FILTERED intel? https://t.co/DJknFejEmA pic.twitter.com/FJpWnb3tA6 ‚Äî RT (@RT_com) August 5, 2025 Cosgrove: ‚ÄúPresident Zelensky just signed a law allowing for citizens age 60 and above to serve in the military,‚Äù Cosgrove said. ‚ÄúWe've seen dozens of videos of young men being hauled into vans and dragged to the front lines against their will... even a young man with Down syndrome serving on the front line.‚Äù ‚ÄúYou said you wanted ‚Äòto see the people stop dying‚Äô... Now the people dying are elderly, mentally handicapped, and conscripts.‚Äù These videos are very disturbing! A man with Down syndrome is serving on the frontlines in Ukraine and is being abused by another squad member, who records it for entertainment. pic.twitter.com/gGiV3jORzz ‚Äî I Meme Therefore I Am üá∫üá∏ (@ImMeme0) February 11, 2024 Cosgrove: ‚ÄúEven if a ceasefire doesn't work out, why should Americans continue to fund a foreign military that‚Äôs scraping the bottom of the barrel like this?‚Äù Trump responded that he had not heard about these actions by the Ukrainian military: ‚ÄúI haven‚Äôt heard that,‚Äù referring to the specifics about Ukraine‚Äôs military draft, but reiterated that former President Biden was to blame for the bloodshed. ‚ÄúThis is Biden‚Äôs war. This is not my war. I‚Äôm here to get us out of it.‚Äù Cursed be anyone who supports this vile fascist regimeüñïüñïüñï pic.twitter.com/ChLX0Ny8I5 ‚Äî Anatolij Sharij (@anatoliisharii) July 29, 2025 He described the Ukraine war as ‚Äúthe one we‚Äôre working hardest on,‚Äù adding that he brokered five ceasefires in his second term and that he‚Äôd ‚Äúlike this to be the sixth.‚Äù One can only hope. Tyler Durden Tue, 08/05/2025 - 23:00

The U.S. trade deficit narrowed, but a services sector activity measure showed rising costs due to import taxes. While earnings reports are mostly beating expectations, concerns about future tariff impacts and slowing travel demand linger, influencing market sentiment.

No proposal to stop supply of Rs 500 notes: MoS Finance
summary: The government has no plans to stop the supply of ‚Çπ500 notes, and ATMs will continue to dispense them along with ‚Çπ100 and ‚Çπ200 denominations, Minister of State for Finance Pankaj Chaudhary told Parliament.
fullContent: The government has no plans to stop the supply of ‚Çπ500 notes, and ATMs will continue to dispense them along with ‚Çπ100 and ‚Çπ200 denominations, Minister of State for Finance Pankaj Chaudhary told Parliament. RBI has directed that by September 2025, 75% of ATMs must dispense ‚Çπ100 or ‚Çπ200 notes, rising to 90% by March 2026.

summary: Adani Ports' net profit increased to Rs 3,314.59 crore. This rise is due to strong revenue growth. Revenue from operations also saw a jump. Logistics and marine businesses showed extraordinary momentum. Cargo volume reached 121 million metric tonnes.
fullContent: Adani Ports' net profit increased to Rs 3,314.59 crore. This rise is due to strong revenue growth. Revenue from operations also saw a jump. Logistics and marine businesses showed extraordinary momentum. Cargo volume reached 121 million metric tonnes. Motilal Oswal and Avendus have retained a 'Buy' rating for Adani Ports. They project continued growth in cargo volumes, revenue, and EBITDA.

title: CFO churn: Most finance bosses exit in 2 years
summary: A significant churn in CFO positions across corporate India is observed, with nearly 70% exiting within two years, as revealed by Ishwa Consulting's data. Misaligned mandates and unclear decision rights trigger almost half of these departures, overshadowing performance issues.
fullContent: A significant churn in CFO positions across corporate India is observed, with nearly 70% exiting within two years, as revealed by Ishwa Consulting's data. Misaligned mandates and unclear decision rights trigger almost half of these departures, overshadowing performance issues. The trend varies across sectors, with faster-moving industries experiencing higher turnover, and internal promotions showing greater retention.

Beware The AI Industrial Complex
summary: Beware The AI Industrial Complex div property="schema:text" class="clearfix text-formatted field field--name-body field--type-text-with-summary field--label-hidden.
fullContent: Beware The AI Industrial Complex By John deVadoss What makes an industrial complex is frontier technology, with feedback loops powerful enough to steer both markets and public policy. Economists describe five telltale traits: mutual dependency between state and suppliers; capital costs so high that only a few firms can play; standards written by insiders; external costs shifted to the public; and a strategic framing (‚Äúnational security,‚Äù ‚Äúglobal competitiveness‚Äù) that evades scrutiny. By that definition, we are witnessing the construction of an AI industrial complex, and its socioeconomic wake is already visible. The early externalities: Power and water The International Energy Agency projects that, by 2030, global data‚Äëcenter electricity demand will double to roughly 945 TWh ‚Äî a trillion watts used per hour. That is about the annual consumption of Japan. Much of that growth is traceable to AI inference and training workloads. The strain is leaking into household bills. In Virginia, Dominion Energy has requested a $10.92/month fuel‚Äërate increase for the ‚Äútypical‚Äù home customer, citing higher gas prices and PJM capacity charges driven in part by data‚Äëcenter growth. The request is still pending. Prices in PJM‚Äôs latest capacity auction cleared 22 % higher than last year; the East Coast grid operator estimates that will add between 1.5% and 5 % to retail bills beginning next summer. Electricity is only half the story. Google‚Äôs environmental report shows its hyperscale facilities used nearly 6 billion gallons of fresh water in 2024, up 8 % year‚Äëon‚Äëyear, a jump Google attributes largely to AI. The company says it ‚Äúreplenished‚Äù 64 % of that total, but the replenishment often happens far from the aquifers it drains. Out West, drought‚Äëstressed cities respond by digging deeper municipal wells or raising water rates ‚Äî expenses that never appear on a quarterly earnings call. Labor and looming AI divide: Whither the middle class? Generative AI in its first iteration targets the heart of the middle‚Äëclass office and clerical economy. Brookings finds more than 30 % of U.S. workers could see at least half of their tasks disrupted, with mid‚Äëskill professional roles most exposed. Public anxiety is tracking the data: A 2024 Governance AI survey shows about half of Americans expect AI to widen income inequality, and two‚Äëthirds want federal action to cushion job losses. The paradox: The same families paying higher utility bills may also face stagnant wages or displacement in the very sectors AI automates. Access to front‚Äëof‚Äëthe‚Äëline models already carries a price tag ‚Äî ChatGPT Plus costs $20 a month, and enterprise ‚ÄúPro‚Äù tiers are tenfold higher. When homework help and job‚Äëapplication prep migrate behind priority tokens, the complex threatens to hard‚Äëcode a two‚Äëtier digital citizenship: seamless for those who can pay, throttled for those who cannot. The new and irreparable digital divide will be between those who know how to work with AI and those who do not. Unlike the paternalistic and naive exhortations to learn to code, this is not about coding or even about software at all ‚Äî this divide is about critical thinking, first-principles reasoning, and the ability to harness an emergent capability that can manifest both cloying sycophancy and Machiavellian deception. The predictable response: UBI, with Big AI as the adjudicator Inevitably, the drums will begin to beat across the nation for so-called universal basic income and its ilk; the state will have to devise economic mechanisms to address unemployment and the increasing replacement of both white and blue-collar jobs; but at what cost? The social contract will have to be rewritten; AI will increasingly assume the roles of fact-checker, arbiter and judge; and Big AI will loom large in the enforcement and governance of this new contract, as the state is forced to reinvent itself. ‚ÄúNeed more training data‚Äù is the cry, and intellectual property is collateral damage; we are witnessing the vestiges of the publishing industry attempting to make a quick buck as copyrights are being railroaded. History is written by winners, and it remains to be seen how the winning AI models and their trainers shape what will count as downstream history. The American spirit owes its striking characteristic to the frontier ‚Äî Americans have always shaped our environment and our tools, not the other way around. But we are at a critical juncture. Are we going to let AI shape our socioeconomic future? Are we about to voluntarily swap our frontier spirit for a gilded cage of our own making? The first meaningful step in addressing this is the rolling back of the proposed moratorium on state and local AI laws in H.R.1 (aka the ‚ÄúBig Beautiful Bill‚Äù). Considering the deep socio-economic impact of AI, it‚Äôs crucial that regulatory authority stays with local governments. A decentralized approach enables state-level experimentation, tailors oversight and risk management to local needs, and increases the likelihood of harnessing AI‚Äôs potential for the common good. About the author: John deVadoss: is a former general manager at Microsoft Corp. in Redmond. He led architecture strategy for .NET, SOA and the early SaaS/Cloud initiatives at Microsoft. Tyler Durden Tue, 08/05/2025 - 22:35
